_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.1    SITE INFORMATION

The main operation of Delta Deer Park is contract chemical packaging, warehousing and distribution.  The facility was completed and began packaging operation in 1998.  The facility is situated on approximately 9 acres located at 334 Tidal Road in Deer Park, Texas 77536.

1.2    ACIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICES

Delta Deer Park is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, instillation, operating procedures, maintenance and employee training on facility processes. It is DeltaA?s policy to implement appropriate controls to reduce and prevent the release of regulated substances. Delta has trained emergency response personnel on site for release response.

1.3     THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED

The Delta Deer Park facilityA?s primary activities are packaging, warehousing and distribution of chemicals. The regulated substances handled by the facility are listed below.  Delta Deer Park receives the regulated substances in bulk tanker trucks, rail cars and iso tanks and transfers them to 55-gallon drums, 275 gallon totes and other smaller containers.  Filled containers are then warehoused or shipped depending on customer specifications.  Inventory is dependent upon customer orders and not all regulated substances are always present onsite. 

       Chemical                        CAS No.

Toxic Substances:    

Toluene 2,4 Diisocyanate      584-84-9
Toluene 2,6 Diisocyanate      91-08-7
Ethylenediamine                      107-15-3

1.4    THE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Delta Deer Park is the operator of a stationary source that has more than the threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process, as determined under 40 CFR 68.115 and therefore is subject to 40 CFR Part 68 A? Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.  Delta Deer Park is a Program 2

level facility.

To evaluate the worst case and alternative scenarios, EPAA?s RMP*Comp program was used to evaluate off-site consequences.  RMP*Comp is based on the look-up tables and equations provided by the EPA in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance.  The following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios.

The worst-case scenarios for the two toxic regulated chemicals involve the catastrophic failure of a rail car (est. 17,300 gallons.) and a tanker truck (est. 6,000 gallons). The alternative release scenarios for the two toxic chemicals involve the puncture of a drum and release of its entire contents inside the warehouse, (est. 55 gallons). Neither one of these scenarios is likely to result in the actual loss of the entire amount of the regulated substances from the vessel because of onsite personnel and other mitigation techniques, but for the worst case and alternative case scenarios these situations were used as potential possibilities that could have offsite consequences, as required by 40 CFR 68.25 and 40 CFR 68.28.


1.5    THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Delta Deer Park has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68. The packaging and warehouse process at the facility is not subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119. Delta Deer Park is subject to EPCRA Section 313 notification requirements. The following sections briefly describe elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the stationary source.

Process Safety Information  
Delta Deer Park maintains a record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the process. 

Process Hazard Review
This facility conducts process hazard reviews to ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled efficiently. The checklist and what

if methods are used to carry out the process hazard analyses. The process hazard analysis is undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and is revised as needed when there is a change in the process. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. 

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered process, Delta Deer Park maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after maintenance. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.

Training
Delta Deer Park has a training program in place to ensure that employees are competent in the operating procedures associated with those processes. New employees receive training before starting work. Operating procedures are reviewed annually and more frequently as needed. 

Mechanical Integrity 
Delta Deer Park carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks include among others; pressure valves and systems, hoses and piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdowns systems and controls. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. These personnel receive specialized on the job training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a timely manner. 

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Delta Deer Park to manage changes in chemicals being packaged, technology, equipment and procedures. Process operators and maintenance personnel whose job tasks are affected by a change or modification of process conditions are made aware of the changes.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-star

tup safety reviews related to new processes and modifications in existing processes are conducted as needed. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment in operation.

Compliance Audits
Delta Deer Park conducts compliance audits to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits will be carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions as a result of the audits will be undertaken promptly. 

Incident Investigation
Delta Deer Park promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the root cause of the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the incident from recurring. Reports are retained in the web based CMS system.

Employee Participation
Delta Deer Park believes that incident prevention is a team effort and involves employees in the incident prevention process. Delta employees have access to the information created as part of facilityA?s implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses. 

Contractors
On occasion, the company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Delta Deer Park has a policy of informing the contactors of known potential hazards related to the contactorA?s works. Contractors are also informed of emergency procedures should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

1.6     FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There has been no release of RMP chemicals at the Delta Deer Park site over the past 5 years.
 
1.7    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Delta Deer Park has a written emergency response plan for responding to accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan covers the aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treat

ment, evacuations, notifications of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident return to work procedure. 

The plan is updated regularly to reflect relevant changes taking place within the process that would require a modified emergency response.

1.8    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFTY

Delta Deer Park has discontinued packaging formaldehyde as a direct result of the scenario modeling required by the RMP plan. Delta has a continuous improvement policy in place that includes safety improvement.
